page.title: 16LOCAL HISTORY.
page.content: The history of these villages is a matter of pride. Wisley was an Iron Age settlement, perhaps older, and Pyrford has visible traces of that time. Both have unrestored Norman churches-Pyrford's just outside this block. There are fine listed buildings and conservation areas, particularly in Ripley and Ockham. The boundaries of Pyrford were outlined in 956 AD. Ripley, too, has Norman origins. Its 66 acres green, the largest in the country escaped enclosure. After the stage coach era it became a famous venue for cycling clubs. Nearby the ruins of Newark Priory, 1199, occupy the one dry part of the water meadows. Wisley's Decoy was a game bird pool on the Pyrford Place estate, once a rival to Clandon. Ockham, rebuilt by the Lovelace's in the C19, was run as a feudal estate until sold in 1955.
